docs.lead_paragraph: A Chinese factory near here will soon begin exporting to the United States RU-486, the abortion pill recently approved by the Food and Drug Administration, an official at the factory confirmed today. The Hualian Pharmaceutical Company, which owns the factory near the coast 25 miles south of Shanghai, has been making the drug since 1992 for use in the domestic market, where it is used to perform millions of abortions each year.

headline.main: Chinese Factory to Soon Begin Exporting Recently Approved Abortion Pills to U.S.

docs.abstract: Hualian Pharmaceutical Co's factory near Shanghai, China, will soon begin exporting to US the abortion pill RU-486, which was recently approved by Food and Drug Administration; Hualian Pharmaceutical has been making drug since 1992 for use in domestic market, where it is used to perform millions of abortions each year; Sen Tim Hutchinson scores deal; pills, known by trade name Mifepristone, will be marketed in US by Danco Laboratories, company set up by nonprofit Population Council of New York (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: New York State will receive $25 million out of the $255 million that six leading vitamin producers will pay to most states in the latest settlement of cases stemming from a decade-long international price-fixing scheme, the state's attorney general said yesterday. The total settlement is divided into three parts: $118 million to 21 states for higher costs to consumers as a result of the price-fixing; $30 million to 47 states for higher charges the states themselves paid for vitamin products; and $107 million to businesses, like farms and retail stores, that were penalized by higher wholesale prices for products containing vitamins, a spokesman for Eliot Spitzer, the New York attorney general, said.

headline.main: New York State to Get $25 Million in Vitamin Antitrust Case

docs.abstract: Atty Gen Eliot Spitzer says New York State will receive $25 million out of $255 million that six leading vitamin producers will pay to most states in latest settlement of cases stemming from decade-long international price-fixing acheme; state will return $19 million of its share to public through nonprofit groups and municipalities for programs dealing with prenatal care, child nutrition and hunger; will keep $6 million as compensation for higher prices it paid for vitamin-containing products; companies agreeing to payments are Hoffmann-La Roche, BASF, Aventis, Takeda, Eisai and Daiichi (M)
docs.snippet: New York State will receive $25 million out of the $255 million that six leading vitamin producers will pay to most states in the latest settlement of cases stemming from a decade-long international price-fixing scheme, the state's attorney general...

docs.lead_paragraph: The subject of reproductive rights has long been difficult terrain for politicians. Abortion is an intensely private question and a moral issue for many Americans, but the debate over reproductive rights is also about the broader cultural struggle over women's social and economic autonomy and the role of government in policing the most private sphere of American life. So it is not surprising that though abortion rights have been constitutionally protected for a generation, the political and cultural battle over this issue rages undiminished 27 years after Roe v. Wade. As Vice President Al Gore said in his first debate with Gov. George W. Bush, the issue of abortion rights ''is on the ballot in this election, make no mistake about it.'' It emerged as a point of difference in the vice-presidential debate and the one on Sunday between Hillary Rodham Clinton and Rick Lazio in the Senate race in New York, and is animating Congressional and state legislative races across the nation.
docs.abstract: Editorial says that while states have increased attacks on abortion, it is the president, Congress and Supreme Court that will utlimately determine limits of reproductive freedom; says majority of Americans continue to support abortion rights, and for many that issue will be a key factor in their vote for next president
docs.snippet: The subject of reproductive rights has long been difficult terrain for politicians. Abortion is an intensely private question and a moral issue for many Americans, but the debate over reproductive rights is also about the broader cultural struggle...

docs.lead_paragraph: The Yakama Nation was hoping to temper the ravages of alcohol abuse when it banned alcohol sales on its reservation in south central Washington. But most tavern owners on the reservation are not members of the tribe and have continued selling liquor after the ban was enacted three weeks ago.

headline.main: Indians and Washington State Are at Odds Over Alcohol Ban

docs.abstract: Yakama Nation has banned alcohol sales on its reservation in south central Washington state but most tavern owners on reservation are not members of tribe and are continuing to sell liquor; state attorney general is suing tribe, contending that Yakama Nation cannot impose its regulations on 20,000 nontribal residents of the reservation (M)
docs.snippet: The Yakama Nation was hoping to temper the ravages of alcohol abuse when it banned alcohol sales on its reservation in south central Washington.    But most tavern owners on the reservation are not members of the tribe and have continued selling...

docs.lead_paragraph: Parents today are certainly better prepared than their parents were to talk with their teenagers about sex. But even though they have their post-sexual-revolution experiences to draw on and a wealth of books to guide them through the Big Talk, many still find it awkward and embarrassing. A survey announced last week by the Henry J. Kaiser Family Foundation, a health research organization, found that parents were looking for help: the overwhelming majority wanted schools to provide more, not less, education on a whole range of sex-related topics once children reached their teenage years.

headline.main: Teaching Teenagers a Subject Many Know All Too Well

docs.abstract: Many parents still find it awkward and embarrassing to talk to their teenagers about sex; survey by Henry J Kaiser Family Foundation finds that overwhelming majority of parents want schools to provide more, not less, education on whole range of sex-related topics once children reach their teenage years; their discomfort has intensified in recent years because teenagers are having sex earlier; study shows that 31 percent in United States had intercourse by age 15 in 1995; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Parents today are certainly better prepared than their parents were to talk with their teenagers about sex. But even though they have their post-sexual-revolution experiences to draw on and a wealth of books to guide them through the Big Talk, many...

docs.lead_paragraph: Following are excerpts from yesterday's debate between the New York senatorial candidates, Hillary Rodham Clinton and Representative Rick A. Lazio, as recorded by The New York Times. The full text is available at The New York Times on the Web at www.nytimes.com. MARCIA KRAMER -- Good morning. I'm Marcia Kramer, political correspondent for WCBS-TV. Well, the stage is set, our candidates are here. Democratic candidate Hillary Clinton and Republican candidate Rick Lazio. I'm joined by our panel of reporters who will be joining me in questioning the candidates. First, CNN senior political correspondent Jeff Greenfield; New York Daily News political columnist Lars-Erik Nelson; New York Times columnist Joyce Purnick; and representing The New York Post, political reporter Gregg Birnbaum. . . . Mrs. Clinton, figures from the Independent Budget Office show that New York State lost over $200 million in federal aid after Chuck Schumer defeated Senator Al D'Amato and New York no longer had a senator in the majority party. Since the Senate is expected to stay in the Republican hands, how would you deliver for the State of New York as a junior senator from a minority party, and a person that the Republicans would clearly want to humiliate?

headline.main: CAMPAIGN 2000: The New York Senate Debate; Excerpts From Second Debate Between Mrs. Clinton and Lazio

docs.lead_paragraph: Following are excerpts from yesterday's debate between New Jersey senatorial candidates Jon S. Corzine and Representative Bob Franks, as recorded by The New York Times. Tom Moran of The Star-Ledger was the moderator. More excerpts are available at The New York Times on the Web at www.nytimes.com. TOM MORAN -- Welcome to the first debate between the major candidates for the U.S. Senate from New Jersey. They are Democrat Jon Corzine, former chairman of the investment firm Goldman Sachs, who is seeking his first public office, and Republican Bob Franks, a member of Congress since his election in 1992 and former chairman of the state Republican Party. The debate is sponsored by The Star-Ledger. It's being broadcast on News 12 New Jersey, CN8 and C-Span. The candidates are competing for the seat held by Democrat Frank Lautenberg, who is retiring from the Senate after 18 years. . . .

headline.main: CAMPAIGN 2000: The New Jersey Senate Debate; Excerpts From Debate Between Bob Franks and Jon S. Corzine

docs.lead_paragraph: The Miss Navajo Pageant isn't about sex. It's about cultural preservation. That's why there's no swimsuit competition, and contestants spend about as much time in standard pageant-issue evening gowns as it takes to boil an egg. ''If there was a swimsuit competition, I would never enter,'' said 19-year-old Leslie John, one of the dozens of junior princesses and regional Miss Navajos who came last month to watch the five-day pageant in Window Rock, Ariz. ''I could have smelled like sheep, and it would have been fine.'' Indeed, the year before, contenders for the Miss Navajo crown had competed in sheep butchering. ''You need the hooves to hang it up with,'' recalled Floranda Dempsey, the only one of this year's four contestants who competed last year. ''But we cut their whole hooves off. We made a huge mess.'' She laughed. ''It was a female. We cut into the breast. Milk everywhere!'' Instead, the women, outfitted most of the time in moccasins and crushed velvet dresses or tunics that resemble Navajo rugs, with their hair pulled back, had to explain the background of the Treaty of 1868 -- in Navajo. And card wool. And spin it. And demonstrate rug weaving. (Some of the modern contests involved demonstrating CPR, reciting Natalie Merchant lyrics in poetic form and doing aerobics.) They seemed to have the hardest time when they each built a fire, heaped shortening in pans and prepared fry bread -- a traditional food that resembles a Frisbee-size sopaipilla. Karletta Chief, a Ph.D. candidate in environmental engineering and science at Stanford and the daughter of a Baptist preacher, stared angrily at the frying pan resting on her fire. A judge had asked her, in Navajo, about lighting the fire, and she had answered using the word ''liver'' when she meant to say ''bark.'' Valerie Jones, who has a degree in social work from Northern Arizona University, struggled to keep her fire going and looked sad. She had said ''lightning'' instead of ''match.'' (''Those elderly lady judges,'' she noted afterward, ''they really scare us. Because we respect them so much.'') Dempsey, whose spoken Navajo has improved significantly since a medicine man addressed the problem with a ceremony for her, encountered a different problem: she usually uses powdered milk in her recipe, but the pageant hadn't provided any.

headline.main: The Way We Live Now: 10-08-00: Phenomenon; Crowning Miss Navajo

docs.abstract: Article on annual Miss Navajo Pageant in Window Rock, Ariz, where contestants compete in cultural skills such as carding and spinning wool, rug weaving, building fires and preparing fry bread and more modern pursuits such as CPR and aerobics; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Each month, at least one woman comes into Katterman's Sand Point Pharmacy in Seattle to ask for a prescription drug. None of the women have seen or spoken to a doctor but each says she needs the drug immediately. The routine for a pharmacist there, Beverly Schaefer, never varies. First she ushers the woman into a private cubicle. Then she counsels them and gives them the prescription pill.

headline.main: Without Fanfare, Morning-After Pill Gets a Closer Look

docs.abstract: Public health officials say emergency contraceptive pill that can prevent pregnancy if taken within 72 hours after intercourse is part of revolution that is potentially as important as one initiated by recent approval of abortion-inducing pill, RU-486; say while RU-486 offers way to end pregnancies, emergency contraceptive pill, known as Plan B, can prevent pregnancies; groups in several states expect to provide Plan B pill to women who have not seen doctor first; in state of Washington, 155 pharmacies are providing pill under those circumstances; pilot programs in Alaska, California and Oregon will soon make emergency contraceptives available without requiring that women see doctor first; Norway is first country to make similar drug, NorLevo, available over the counter; history of Plan B detailed; phtos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: With many parents citing the threat of AIDS, a recent survey by the Henry J. Kaiser Family Foundation has found overwhelming support among parents for sex education in America's high schools. A strong majority of parents surveyed wanted schools to cover not just the biology of reproduction and the dangers of sexually transmitted diseases, but also issues like abortion and sexual orientation. The findings also did not divide neatly between those who favor teaching abstinence until marriage, and those who favor comprehensive sex education.
